references: We can now state upper bounds on convergence (to an error smaller than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) for the respective mixed FL algorithms. For ease of comparison, the convergence bounds are summarized in Table 1. The Theorems and Proofs of these convergence bounds are given in Appendix B. As mentioned previously, the analysis extends in a straightforward manner to the setting of heterogeneous clients assuming a bound on the variance of client gradients: for all 𝒙𝒙\bm{x}, 1N​∑i=1N‖∇fi​(𝒙)−∇ff​(𝒙)‖2≤σf21𝑁superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑁superscriptnorm∇subscript𝑓𝑖𝒙∇subscript𝑓f𝒙2superscriptsubscript𝜎f2\frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^{N}\|\nabla f_{i}(\bm{x})-\nabla f_{\textrm{f}}(\bm{x})\|^{2}\leq\sigma_{\textrm{f}}^{2} for some σf≥0subscript𝜎f0\sigma_{\textrm{f}}\geq 0. Under this assumption, the bounds in Table 1 change by an additional K​σf2𝐾superscriptsubscript𝜎f2K\sigma_{\textrm{f}}^{2} term in the expression involving σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} and σc2superscriptsubscript𝜎c2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} in the parenthesis on the numerator of the leading term. We omit the detailed analysis since it doesn’t provide additional insight.
Analyzing Table 1, there are several implications to be drawn.

It is interesting to reflect on the bounds of Table 1, and what they indicate about the benefits of separating a single decentralized client population into multiple populations for mixed FL purposes. The bounds are in terms of σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} (representing within population ‘variability’) and G𝐺G and B𝐵B (representing cross-population ‘variability’). Splitting a population based on traits will likely decrease σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} (each population is now more homogeneous) but introduce or increase G𝐺G and B𝐵B (populations are now distinctive). This might indicate scenarios where Gradient Transfer methods (only bounded by σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2}) become more useful and Parallel Training (also bound by G𝐺G and B𝐵B) becomes less useful.

Note that the convergence bounds of Table 1 hold for K≥2𝐾2K\geq 2, so this takes us outside the operating regime where the bounds predict performance. It also takes us outside an operating regime that is typically useful (FL use cases generally find multiple steps per round to be beneficial). But it does serve a purpose when debugging.

The three subsections that follow state theorems for convergence (to an error smaller than ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilon) for the respective mixed FL algorithms. The convergence bounds are summarized in Table 1 in Section 4. Tables 3 and 4 convey some supporting aspects of the convergence bounds, about limits on effective step size (η~=η​ηs​K~𝜂𝜂subscript𝜂s𝐾\tilde{\eta}=\eta\eta_{\textrm{s}}K) and assumptions on learning rates.

Table 1 shows that the theoretical bounds on rounds to convergence are directly proportional to the client variance bound σ2superscript𝜎2\sigma^{2} and central variance bound σc2superscriptsubscript𝜎c2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2}. Also, as discussed in Subsection 4.2, 1-way Gradient Transfer is more sensitive to high central variance than the other two algorithms. Whereas in the other algorithms the impact of σc2superscriptsubscript𝜎c2\sigma_{\textrm{c}}^{2} on convergence scales with cohort size S𝑆S, in 1-way Gradient Transfer it scales with cohort size S𝑆S and steps taken per round K𝐾K.

The convergence bounds of Table 1 have an additional implication, in regards to the trade off between client learning rate η𝜂\eta (and central learning rate ηcsubscript𝜂c\eta_{\textrm{c}}) and number of local steps taken K𝐾K.

Some of this behavior has been observed empirically, when hyperparameter tuning our experiments (discussed in Subsection C.2). For example, for the language modeling experiment, assuming a constant number of steps of K=16𝐾16K=16, 2-way Gradient Transfer tends to diverge when learning rate η𝜂\eta was increased beyond 1.0, whereas 1-way Gradient Transfer is observed to converge even with learning rate η𝜂\eta of 5.0. (Parallel Training is in-between; it still converges with learning rate η𝜂\eta of 3.0, but diverges when learning rate η𝜂\eta is 5.0.) An interesting characteristic to note is that using different η𝜂\eta in different algorithms does not really impact comparative convergence. Figure 10 shows convergence in the language modeling experiment, when 2-way Gradient Transfer uses η=1.0𝜂1.0\eta=1.0 and 1-way Gradient Transfer and Parallel Training both use η=3.0𝜂3.0\eta=3.0 (in all cases, with K=16𝐾16K=16). The higher learning rate of 1-w GT and PT helps a little early, but does not impact the number of rounds to convergence. This holds with the theoretical convergence bounds of Table 1, which show a relationship with steps K𝐾K but not learning rates (as also discussed above).

references: Under such IID conditions, if FedAvg is used to train 𝒙𝒙\bm{x} on these federated clients, the convergence rate at best matches that of SGD (see Table 2 in Karimireddy et al. (2020b)).

In that work, it was empirically observed that 1-way Gradient Transfer converged faster than Parallel Training. Figures 1a and 2a show the AUC and loss convergence, adding in 2-way Gradient Transfer (first introduced in this paper)101010For training hyperparameters, additional experiments, and other details, see Appendix C.. Note that 2-way Gradient Transfer performs as good or better than the other algorithms. The analysis of Section 4 provides the explanation for the empirical observation that Gradient Transfer converges faster than Parallel Training. As discussed, Parallel Training is at a disadvantage when G≫0much-greater-than𝐺0G\gg 0 or B≫1much-greater-than𝐵1B\gg 1, and Table 2 (left column) shows that G~tsubscript~𝐺𝑡\tilde{G}_{t} is significantly large in this problem.

Table 2 (center column) shows G~tsubscript~𝐺𝑡\tilde{G}_{t} and B~tsubscript~𝐵𝑡\tilde{B}_{t} for this problem. Unlike smile classification, here gradient dissimilarity is trivial: G~t≈0subscript~𝐺𝑡0\tilde{G}_{t}\approx 0 and B~t≈1subscript~𝐵𝑡1\tilde{B}_{t}\approx 1. This should mean Parallel Training is competitive. Figure 2b empirically confirms this to be true; the algorithms converge roughly equivalently.

Figure 5.3 shows that Parallel Training converges slightly slower than either Gradient Transfer algorithm but reaches the same evaluation loss at around 1500 rounds. The approximated gradient dissimilarity metrics for this task are presented in the last column of Table 2.

Table 2 is an informative comparison of the mixed FL optimization landscape of the three respective experiments conducted in Section 5. It includes maximum values for the metrics G~tsubscript~𝐺𝑡\tilde{G}_{t} and B~tsubscript~𝐵𝑡\tilde{B}_{t} (the sampled approximations of the parameters defined in (G,B𝐺𝐵G,B)-BGD (Definition 4.2). Here we provide some additional information.

references: Table 3 in Appendix B shows that in order to yield the convergence bounds stated in this paper, each algorithm makes different assumptions of maximum effective step size. From this we draw one final implication in regards to comparing the mixed FL algorithms.

The maximum effective step sizes of Table 3 imply that 2-way Gradient Transfer has narrower limits than 1-way Gradient Transfer on the allowable ranges of η𝜂\eta and K𝐾K. It also indicates that for Parallel Training the allowable range of η𝜂\eta, ηcsubscript𝜂c\eta_{\textrm{c}}, and K𝐾K depends on the B𝐵B parameter from mixed FL (G,B𝐺𝐵G,B)-BGD (Definition 4.2).

A3.T5.caption: Table 5: Computation and communication overheads for Movie Recommendation task.
references: Experiments show that all mixed FL algorithms achieve model performance (around 0.1 for recall@10) comparable to the baseline scenario where everything is computed on the clients. Moreover, mixed FL eliminates more than 99.9% of client computation and more than 93.9% of communication (see Table 5.3). For training hyperparameters, computation and communication savings analysis, additional experiments, and other task details, see Appendix C. Note that a real-world model can be much larger than this movie recommendation model131313E.g., for a next URL prediction task with millions of URLs the embedding table size can reach gigabytes.. Without mixed FL, communicating such large models to clients and computing the regularization term would be impractical in large-scale settings.
figureNext movie prediction performance (evaluation loss vs. training round). We see that mixed FL results in similar loss as the more expensive baseline scenario (see Table 5.3).

As shown in the second row of Table 5, the amount of computation for regularization term is (K⋅N2⋅d)/2⋅𝐾superscript𝑁2𝑑2(K\cdot N^{2}\cdot d)/2 if calculating on-device (baseline). When computing the regularization term on the server (mixed FL), the complexity is (N2⋅d)/2⋅superscript𝑁2𝑑2(N^{2}\cdot d)/2. The total computation saving with mixed FL is ((K−1)⋅N2⋅d)/2⋅𝐾1superscript𝑁2𝑑2((K-1)\cdot N^{2}\cdot d)/2. We use (N2⋅d)/2⋅superscript𝑁2𝑑2(N^{2}\cdot d)/2 instead of N2⋅d⋅superscript𝑁2𝑑N^{2}\cdot d for regularization term computation which is more accurate for an optimized implementation.

The communication overheads of each algorithm are presented in the last row of Table 5. For the baseline, the server and each client need to communicate the full embedding table and the gradients, so the communication overhead is 2⋅N⋅d⋅2𝑁𝑑2\cdot N\cdot d or 494KB. With Parallel Training, the server and each client only communicate movie embeddings and the gradients corresponding to movies in that client’s local datasets. Thus the communication traffic is reduced to 2⋅n⋅d⋅2𝑛𝑑2\cdot n\cdot d or 20KB. Gradient Transfer requires the server to send both the movie embeddings and gradients to each client. The communication overhead then becomes 3⋅n⋅d⋅3𝑛𝑑3\cdot n\cdot d or 30KB. Overall, mixed FL can save more than 93.9% communication overhead than the baseline.
